[[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|Spanish conquest]] was focused on the establishment of the [[QuerÃ©taro, QuerÃ©taro|Santiago de QuerÃ©taro]], which still dominates the state culturally, economically and educationally. == Geography, climate and ecology == [[File:SotanodelBarro.jpg|thumb|left|Sotano de Barro in the Sierra Gorda]] QuerÃ©taro is located in the north-central area of the country of Mexico, connecting the wetter climes of the south with the drier deserts of the north. Elevations here range between 900 masl and 3,000 masl. The [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]] occupies about half of the state in the center and south. Those in the mountains are closer culturally to those living on the Gulf coast, with the latter have more in common with cultures found in the west of Mexico and the [[Mexican Plateau|central highlands]] .{{cite web |url= http://www.inafed.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/queretaro/ |title= Historia |year=2005 |work= Enciclopedia de los Municipios de MÃ©xico QuerÃ©taro |publisher= Instituto Nacional para el Federalismo y el Desarrollo Municipal |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans_title=History |accessdate=March 12, 2011 }} There are indigenous communities in seven of the eighteen municipalities of the state, mostly [[Otomi people|Otomi]] and [[Pame]]. These communities are located in south in [[Amealco de Bonfil]]. Here there are over 25,000 people in thirty one communities such as San Ildefonso, Tultepec, Santiago MexquititlÃ¡n, ChitejÃ© de la Cruz and San Miguel Tlaxcatltepec. In the arid parts of the center of the state indigenous communities are found in the municipalities of [[TolimÃ¡n, QuerÃ©taro|TolimÃ¡n]], Cadereyta, [[ColÃ³n, QuerÃ©taro|ColÃ³n]] and [[Ezequiel Montes, QuerÃ©taro|Ezequiel Montes]]. However, of all the people in these indigenous communities, only a total of 23,363 spoke an indigenous language, primarily Otomi, as of 2005. 94.8% of these were also speakers of Spanish. == Culture == [[File:ConcursoHuapango07.JPG|thumb|Scene at the 2011 National Huapango Dance Competition in Pinal de Amoles]] Western painting developed in the state during the colonial period, when artists such as Pedro de Rojas LÃ³pez, TomÃ¡s Noriega and Diego Sanabria produced primarily religious art. It has performed in many parts of Mexico as well as in the Americas and Europe.{{cite web |url= http://www.danzamexicofolklorico.com/historial.html |title= MÃ©xico FolklÃ³rico |publisher= Danza Mexico Folklorico |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans_title=Folk Dance of Mexico |accessdate=March 12, 2011 }} The cooking of the Sierra Gorda region is strongly influenced by the Huasteca cuisine of neighboring [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]] and San Luis PotosÃ­ states. One native beverage is called mejengue, with is made with piloncillo, banana, pulque and corn.JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 43. == History == The official name of the state is âEstado Libre y Soberano de QuerÃ©taro de Arteagaâ (Free and Sovereign State of QuerÃ©taro de Arteaga). The formal name of the capital is Santiago de QuerÃ©taro. However, both are commonly referred to simply as QuerÃ©taro. It was returned to Santiago de QuerÃ©taro in 1996, when it was named a [[World Heritage Site]].JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 29. The ending of âde Arteagaâ was added to the stateâs name in 1867 in honor of General [[JosÃ© MarÃ­a Cayetano Arteaga Magallanes]]. Originally from [[Mexico City]], Arteaga became governor of QuerÃ©taro and distinguished himself as a soldier in the middle of the 19th century. Agricultural settlements dated to about 500 BCE have been found in the San Juan del RÃ­o and [[Huimilpan]] area, which was during the [[Teotihuacan]] era. The ancient city had interest and influence in the area because of its agriculture but did not dominate it.JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 28. After the fall of this city, the QuerÃ©tero area had its highest rate of development of both agriculture and social structure. The area was inhabited early on by a number of ethnicities including the [[Otomi people|Otomi]], [[Toltec]]s, [[Chichimeca]]s, [[PâurhÃ©pecha]]s and [[Mexica]]s. In the 10th century, the area experience population shifts which did not stabilize until the 12th century. Much of this migration moved south from the QuerÃ©taro area into the [[Valley of Mexico]]. Those who remained by the end of the 12th century were mostly in hunter-gatherer communities and small agricultural settlements. The regionâs agriculture and minerals continued to attract the interest of more powerful neighbors. In the 15th century, both the [[Aztec Empire|Aztec]] and PâurhÃ©pecha Empires had strong influence parts of the state, especially in the south, but would never incorporate the area completely into either empire. The Aztecâs interest in the area was mostly to use it as a bulwark against marauding northern Chichimeca tribes, and it never became a tributary state. During this time as well, a number of new peoples entered the state most likely from the north, primarily the [[Pame]]s and the [[Chichimeca Jonaz]]. The first group practiced agriculture in the valleys and the latter in the mountain areas. When the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|Spanish conquered the Aztec Empire]] in the early 16th century, the largest indigenous group in the state was the Otomi, many of whom were living more or less under PâurhÃ©pecha rule. [[File:Catedral de QuerÃ©taro.jpg|thumb|Cathedral of QuerÃ©taro]] The conquest and colonization of QuerÃ©taro began with the Spanish settlements at San Juan del RÃ­o, QuerÃ©taro and Huimilpan between 1529 and 1531. [[Conquistador]] [[HerÃ¡n PÃ©rez de Bocanegra]] joined forces with a local Otomi lord from [[Jilotepec]] named [[ConÃ­n]], also known as Fernando de Tapia, to enter Otomi areas in what is now the city of QuerÃ©taro. There would be only one major battle as part of the conquest in 1531. The Spanish and their Indian allies were battling the local Otomi and Chichimecas at a hill now known as Sangremal, which was then called Ynlotepeque, and considered sacred in pre-Hispanic times. Chronicles of this event, such as those written by Friar Isidro FÃ©lix de Espinoza, state that the natives were at the point of winning when a total eclipse of the sun occurred. This supposedly scared the natives and the Spanish claimed to have seen an image of [[James, son of Zebedee|Saint James (the patron saint of Spain)]] riding a white horse carrying a rose-colored cross. This event caused the natives to surrender.{{Cite web |url= http://www.inafed.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/queretaro/ |title= Enciclopedia de los Municipios de MÃ©xico QuerÃ©taro QuerÃ©taro |publisher=INAFED |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |accessdate=2009-11-12 }} This event is why the city is called Santiago (Saint James) de QuerÃ©taro, with James as patron saint{{cite web |url=http://www.elclima.com.mx/santiago_queretaro.htm |title= Santiago, QuerÃ©taro |publisher=El Clima |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |accessdate=2009-11-12 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.frommers.com/destinations/santiagodequeretaro/0926010001.html |title= Introduction to Santiago de Queretaro |publisher=Frommers |location=USA |accessdate=2009-11-12 }} A stone cross imitating the one the Spanish supposedly saw was erected on the hill, which later was accompanied by a church and monastery. During the rest of the 16th century, the Spanish city of QuerÃ©taro would form the northern extension of known lands to the Spanish conquerors. The Spanish initially shared power in the area with local indigenous leaders until well into the 17th century in many areas. However, indigenous power waned over time, eventually disappearing completely. However, the Spanish would not subdue and evangelized the last of the resistant peoples, the Chichimec Jonaz until the end of the 18th century. During this time, Spanish power was mostly concentrated in the city of QuerÃ©taro, which became the starting point for expeditions, missions and conquests heading north. [[File:Atriumcapillasposas.JPG|thumb|Atrim with cross at Tilaco, Landa de Matamoros, one of the five missions attributed to JunÃ­pero Serra]] Most of the north of the state consists of an area known as the [[Sierra Gorda]], which is an area of very rugged terrain, with widely varying climates. From the 16th to 19th centuries The Spanish would slowly dominate the lands around it, south in QuerÃ©taro, west in [[Guanajuato]] and east in [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]], with only military and missionary incursions into the area's interior. This was due to the fierce resistance of the local native peoples. Unlike those in the south, the [[Pame]]s, [[Chichimeca Jonaz]] and other groups were mostly hunter gatherers, not city dwellers already used to a hierarchical governing system. Attempts to militarily pacify and evangelize the area had little success, with a number of missions never completed or destroyed shortly after they were built. In the mid 18th century, the colonial government in Mexico City decided to made a concerted effort to bring the territory into submission, as it contained important routes to mining areas such as [[Zacatecas]] and [[Guanajuato]]. [[JosÃ© de EscondÃ³n]] was sent in 1740 to militarily subdue the area, which culminated in the 1748 [[Battle of Media Luna]], in which the Chichimeca were decisively defeated. This paved the way for the establishment of five principle missions in the heart of the Sierra Gorda of QuerÃ©taro, attributed to JunÃ­pero Serra, which today are a World Heritage Site.{{cite journal |last= Cornejo |first= JosuÃ© |year=2006 |month=Jan Feb |title=La Sierra Gorda de QuerÃ©taro |trans_title=The Sierra Gorda of QuerÃ©taro |journal=ArqueologÃ­a Mexicana |volume=XIII |series=77 |pages=54â63 |location=Mexico City |publisher= Editorial RaÃ­ces S.A. de C.V. |language=Spanish |accessdate=March 29, 2011 |url= http://www.arqueomex.com/S8N4GVesp77.html }}{{cite journal |last= Velasco Mireles |first= Margarita |year=2006 |month=Jan Feb |title= El mundo de la Sierra Gorda |trans_title=The World of the Sierra Gorda |journal=ArqueologÃ­a Mexicana |volume=XIII |series=77 |pages=28-27 |location=Mexico City |publisher= Editorial RaÃ­ces S.A. de C.V. |language=Spanish |accessdate=March 29, 2011 |url= http://www.arqueomex.com/S2N3nSIERRAGORDA77.html }} Even though the area was pacified in the mid 18th century, a district called an "alcaldÃ­a mayor" was established in San JosÃ© de EscandÃ³n, today in the municipality of Pinal de Amoles, which governed what is now the northern half of the state. Decline of mining in the area would have this seat of government moved to Cadereyta in 1675, but this territory would be joined with the alcaldÃ­a mayor of the city of QuerÃ©taro to form the modern state.{{cite web |url= http://www.inafed.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/queretaro/municipios/22002a.htm |title=QuerÃ©taro - Pinal de Amoles |year=2005 |work= Enciclopedia de los Municipios de MÃ©xico |publisher= Instituto Nacional para el Federalismo y el Desarrollo Municipal |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |accessdate=April 4, 2011 }} [[File:Nuestra SeÃ±ora de la Luz de Tancoyol.JPG|thumb|Mission church at Tancoyol]] The territory of QuerÃ©taro was consolidated during the 17th century. Santiago de QuerÃ©taro was declared a city in 1655. The coat of arms granted to the capital city that year is now the state coat of arms, with the substitution of an eagle on a cactus to replace the section referring to the Spanish royalty. Over the colonial period, the QuerÃ©taro area became important strategically and economically as it connected the newly explored and conquered lands to the north and west to the center of [[New Spain]] in Mexico City. Various trade routes converged here and the city became a cultural crossroads. The activities of [[Franciscan]] missionaries were a decisive factor in building the economic, social, political and religious institutions of the state. They were also mostly responsible for the building of most of the religious buildings and the acquisition of paintings and sculptures that can still be seen. These works gave the city an image of richness. The buildings from this era of the cityâs history include the Plaza de Armas, The Casa de Ecala, the Casa de los SeptiÃ©n, the Cassa de los Samaniego, the Casa de los FernÃ¡ndez de JÃ¡uregui, the Palacio de la CorregidurÃ­a de Legres de QuerÃ©taro as well as the CongregaciÃ³n and San Antonio churches. However, the most important structure from the time is the [[Aqueduct of QuerÃ©taro|Aqueduct]]. Much of the evangelization efforts in the [[Sierra Gorda]] area was done by [[JunÃ­pero Serra]]. These efforts left behind a number of missions which exist to this day in [[Jalpan de Serra]], Tancoyol, ConcÃ¡, Tilaco and [[Landa de Matamoros]]. This development made the city wealthy for the rest of the colonial period.JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 29. QuerÃ©taro reached its height of the colonial period during the 18th century due to its strategic position with the northern territories and because of its livestock production. There was also a significant textile industry for local and regional markets. QuerÃ©taro was the first major producer of wool cloth in New Spain. At the end of the century, The Real Fabrica de Tabaco (Royal Tobacco Factory) was established, the second most important of its type in New Spain. The city of QuerÃ©taro was strategic in the development of events just before the start of the [[Mexican War of Independence]]. It was the site of the conspiracy among [[Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla]], [[Ignacio Allende]], [[Josefa Ortiz de DomÃ­nguez]] and her husband the Corregidor of QuerÃ©taro [[Miguel DomÃ­nguez]]. The plot was uncovered when another conspirator, [[Epigmenio GonzÃ¡lez]] was caught with a stockpile of weapons to be used to start the war. Ortiz de Dominguez sent word to Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla in [[Dolores Hidaldo|Dolores, Guanajuato]] that the plot was discovered. At that point, Hidalgo decided to begin the revolt against colonial rule in on 15 September, rather than in December as planned. The city of QuerÃ©taro would be one of the last royalist bastions to fall. After the war, QuerÃ©taro was made a state with the [[1824 Constitution of Mexico|1824 Constitution]] .JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 29-30. However, the city and state would lose the economic and cultural prominence it had during the colonial period. The political instability of the 19th century took its toll on commerce, which made the areaâs economy suffer. The status of QuerÃ©taro would change between state and department, depending on whether Liberals or Conservatives were in power nationally. Within the state, battles for power between the two groups would lead to the state having twenty five governors between 1824 and 1855. During the century, the capital city was the scene of a number of important events. During the [[Mexican American War]], the capital was moved from Mexico City to QuerÃ©taro. At the end of that war, the [[Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo]] was signed here. The [[1857 Constitution of Mexico|1857 Constitution]] was published in the city as well and a coalition of states including QuerÃ©taro, [[Jalisco]], [[Aguascalientes]], [[Zacatecas]], [[Guanajuato]] and [[MichoacÃ¡n]] formed a coalition to defend this constitution against the [[Plan of Tacubaya]]. During the short reign of [[Maximilian I of Mexico|Maximilian I]], there were battles between Liberals and Conservatives (with the latter supporting the emperor) in QuerÃ©taro. However, Maximilian lost the military support provided by [[Napoleon III]], leaving only four states loyal to the emperor. QuerÃ©taro was one of them. Maximilian still resisted Liberal forces which eventually surrounded him at Cerro de Campanas, then outside the city of QuerÃ©taro. The emperor was caught and executed on 19 June 1867. Afterwards, the state wrote a new constitution based on Liberal principles. Another new state constitution would be written at the beginning of the [[Porfirio DÃ­az|Porfiriato]] in 1879. Despite the turmoil, there was still economic progress in the state, with the establishment of textile mills such as HÃ©rcules, Casa Rubio and two other factories in San Antonio and La PurÃ­sma. There was also some mining, especially in El Doctor, RÃ­o Blando, MaconÃ­ and Escanelilla with a total of 216 mines producing silver with some producing gold, copper, lead and more.JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 30. Before the end of the century, modern infrastructure such as electricity, telegraph and telephones began to be installed. Industry grew and modernized, with El HÃ©rcules becoming the largest textile factory in the country. [[Hacienda]]s and agricultural production also grew, especially in the north of the state. The capital was modified and expanded, and it was linked to the rest of the country via rail in 1882. Public education began in the state at the beginning of the 20th century with fifty four primary schools and the first graduates of the stateâs first teachersâ college. However, at the same time, strikes and other movements against the Diaz regime had begun in the state and elsewhere in the country. At the start of the [[Mexican Revolution]], there were revolts in [[Jalpan de Serra]] and Cadereyta along with protests in the capital. Govener [[GonzÃ¡lez de CosÃ­o]] resigned in 1911, replaced by [[JoaquÃ­n F. Chicarro]] who was allied with [[Victoriano Huerta]] and more authoritarian. In 1916 and 1917, the federal government of [[Venustiano Carranza]] had to abandon Mexico City moving the countryâs capital to QuerÃ©taro. The countryâs current [[1917 Constitution of Mexico|1917 Constitution]] was promulgated from Teatro de la RepÃºblica in the city of QuerÃ©taro.JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 31. After the war, the economy of the state recovered slowly. Between 1940 and 1960, economic progress came more rapidly, with the industrial infrastructure growing and modernizing. During the same time period, the population grew substantially as well. Much of industrial growth from then to the present can be seen in the various industrial parks located north of the capital city. In the following thirty years, the city would then grow to over four times its previous size. However, the state managed to conserve the cityâs historic center, which was declared a World Heritage Site in 1996. The cityâs official name, which had been changed simply to âQuerÃ©taroâ was restored to âSantiago de QuerÃ©taroâ the same year. In 1997, the [[National Action Party]] (PAN) won the gubernatorial elections and [[Ignacio Loyola]] became the first non [[Partido Revolucionario Institucional|PRI]] governor of the state since the Revolution. In 2008, the stateâs constitution was amended to make QuerÃ©taro the official state name. The aqueduct [[Acueducto II]] was inaugurated in 2011 by President [[Felipe CalderÃ³n]] and state governor [[JosÃ© Calzada Rovirosa]]. It transports water over 122 km from springs in El Infiernillo to the city of QuerÃ©taro. This is to supplement local water sources which are no longer able to meet the cityâs needs.{{cite news |title= Destacan beneficios de sistema Acueducto II en QuerÃ©taro |agency=Agencia el Universal |newspaper=El Universal |location=Mexico City |date=February 17, 2011 |page= |language=Spanish |trans_title=Highlighting benefits of the Acueduct II in QuerÃ©taro}} == Economy == === General description === Economic activity in the state is closely tied to trends at the national level. This includes the declining contribution to [[GDP]] of the agricultural sector and an increase in manufacturing and commerce/services. The city of QuerÃ©taro is by far the most important economic center in the state, followed by [[San Juan del RÃ­o]]. Not only is QuerÃ©tero the population center of the state, it has high-quality soil for irrigation farming and cattle. It is directly connected by highway to Mexico City, the countryâs largest market, as well as the north of the country and the United States. This makes the city an almost obligatory stop for most people and goods traveling north and south. This geographical advantage has spurred industrial development in the state, especially since the 1970s. Another advantage the state has is its stable social and political situation. It has a low crime rate and also noted by [[NGO]] Transparencia Meixcan as having the lowest levels of corruption among all of Mexicoâs states. Of the three main sectors of the economy: agriculture, mining/industry and commerce/services, the percentage each employs and contributes to the GDP varies significantly from municipality to municipality, with agriculture making up a higher percentage of local employment and GDP in rural municipalities than in the QuerÃ©taro metropolitan area. However, overall, the state has one of the countryâs strongest economies. Government authorities report an increase of 4,602 jobs in the state for January 2011, accounting for a quarter of the gain for the country. Some related to Bombardier.{{cite news |title= QuerÃ©taro genera un cuarto de empleos del paÃ­s |author= Salvador Castillo |url= http://magazinedequeretaro.com/web/lo-nuevo/5942-queretaro-genera-un-cuarto-de-empleos-del-pais.html |newspaper= Magazine de QuerÃ©taro Claroscurovip |location=QuerÃ©taro, Mexico |date=February 19, 2011 |accessdate=March 12, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=QuerÃ©taro generates a quarters of the jobs in the country }} The municipalities of the state are grouped into five economic regions centered on [[Amealco de Bonfil]], Cadereyta de Montes, [[Jalpan de Serra]], QuerÃ©taro and San Juan del RÃ­o. The Amealco region includes this municipality and the municipality of Huimilpan. Most of its economy is based on cereal production with only minor industry such as maquiladoras and textiles. There are also handcrafts produced by indigenous groups.{{cite web |url= http://www.inafed.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/queretaro/ |title= Actividad EconÃ³mica |year=2005 |work= Enciclopedia de los Municipios de MÃ©xico QuerÃ©taro |publisher= Instituto Nacional para el Federalismo y el Desarrollo Municipal |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans_title=Economic Activity |accessdate=March 12, 2011 }} The Cadereyta regiÃ³n includes this municipality, [[ColÃ³n, QuerÃ©taro|ColÃ³n]], [[PeÃ±amiller]] and [[TolimÃ¡n, QuerÃ©taro|TolimÃ¡n]]. Agriculture is limited to the rainy season, but there is significant production of livestock such as goats. There is also some forestry activity. Industry is not common, but some technically advanced factories exist. There are also [[maquiladora]]s, textile and recycling operations which primarily employ women. The Jalpan de Serra region includes this municipality and [[Arroyo Seco, QuerÃ©taro|Arroyo Seco]], [[Pinal de Amoles]], [[Landa de Matamoros]] and [[San JoaquÃ­n, QuerÃ©taro|San JoaquÃ­n]]. Agriculture is limited, mostly producing fruits such as citrus, mangos, coffee, peaches and apples. Fish farming is a growing and promising enterprise for the areas. Industry is also very limited. The QuerÃ©taro regiÃ³n includes the capital and the municipalities of [[Corregidora, Municipality|Corregidora]] and [[El MarquÃ©s]]. This area has the second most productive farms in the state, much of which is irrigated. Crops include [[sorghum]], wheat, [[barley]], [[alfalfa]], [[oats]] with some vegetables, corn and beans. This area is also an important producer of all kinds of livestock. Industry is limited to the industrial parks located just north of the capital, but they employ most of the industrial workers of the state. The San Juan del RÃ­o region includes this municipality and [[Ezequiel Montes, QuerÃ©taro|Ezequiel Montes]], [[Pedro Escobedo, QuerÃ©taro|Pedro Escobedo]] and [[Tequisquiapan]]. This is the most agriculturally production region of the state, with most farmland irrigated. There is intensive farming of sorghum, wheat, barley, alfalfa, and oats, with some vegetables, corn and beans. Large areas of natural pasture supports a large livestock industry. The region is second in industry behind QuerÃ©taro, concentrating on paper products and food processing. Most industry is located in San Juan del RÃ­o. === Agriculture and forestry === [[File:VineyardPeÃ±aBernal2.JPG|thumb|Vineyard belonging to Cavas Freixnet in Ezequiel Montes]] Agriculture and livestock have been traditionally important for the state, and while it only provides about four percent of the stateâs GDP, down from eighteen percent in 1970, it employs a far larger percentage of the population, with it being the basis of the economy in many rural areas. 28,24% of state land is used for agriculture, mostly raising corn, wheat, [[alfalfa]], [[sorghum]] and [[Squash (plant)|squash]]. There is also intensive farming in areas of a number of important crops. Much of the large scale farming is irrigated and is supported in part by the state government, with loans and help with infrastructure such as water and roads. However, most farmland is seasonal, meaning it is worked only during the rainy season. Grains such as barley, wheat, oats and alfalfa are almost exclusively planted on irrigated land along with certain vegetables such as [[broccoli]], garlic, carrots, lettuce, onions and [[cauliflower]]. Most non irrigated land is planted with corn, followed by beans mostly for auto or local consumption. Leading cash crops are beans, [[cabbage]], [[alfalfa]], onions, lettuce and sorghum. Within agriculture, production of crops has decreased while the production of animal products has increased. Crops as a percentage of agricultural production dropped from 34% in 1988 to 25.8% in 1993. One of the leading milk producers in the country, QuerÃ©taro farms also breed livestock and dairy cows. Livestock production is important and growing, mostly consisting of cattle, pigs, sheep, goats, horses and domestic fowl. QuerÃ©taro is one of the top producers of chicken in Mexico. The largest producers of livestock in the state are Jalpan, Cadereyta, San Juan del RÃ­o and QuerÃ©taro. Forest land is one of the stateâs two main natural resources. These forests contain commercial species such as pine, oak, [[Cedrus|cedar]], [[juniper]], [[mesquite]] and more. Most of these are found in and around the Sierra Gorda area. There is about 70,000 hectares of possible productive land but only 17,000 have been studied for management. Land actively involved in forestry operations equals 9,358m2, most of which is in the municipalities of Landa de Matamoros and [[Amealco de Bonfil]]. 20.7% is used for grazing. 24.22% is forest; 3.95% is rainforest and 40.62 is arid scrub brush. === Mining and industry === [[File:MineVizarron1.JPG|thumb|Mine in VizarrÃ³n]] Mining, manufacturing and construction accounts for about 39% of the GDP, with manufacturing alone accounting for 32%. This has remained steady for the past few decades. Minerals is one of the stateâs two main natural resources. Mining is a traditional economic activity for the state. There are ten mining districts in the Sierra Gorda alone producing lead, silver, [[zinc]], copper, gold, [[mercury (element)|mercury]] and [[antimony]]. Non metallic products include marble, [[kaolin]], [[sandstone]], and more. [[Opal]]s are a distinctive state resource. State and local governments, in partnership with private industry, actively promote foreign investment into the region. The priority of the state government is to encourage industries which use low levels of water for environmental reasons. These have mostly been auto parts, food processing and electronics. Other major industries include chemicals, plastics, textiles, paper products and printing and wood products. Most are micro and small sized operations. QuerÃ©taroâs major cities are home to industrial complexes that produce machinery and other metallic products, chemicals and processed foods. However, most of the stateâs manufacturing companies are located in or around the city of QuerÃ©taro. [[Carnation Company|Carnation]] and [[Purina Mills|Purina]] are among the best-known food processing companies with facilities in the state, and numerous textile mills manufacture clothing made of wool, cotton and [[henequen]]. One of the biggest employers is [[Tremac]], an auto parts manufacturer. Currently, there are 392 companies with direct foreign investment and 238 exporting companies that have located in the state. Exports in 2002 totaled $3.35 billion USD, and direct investment in 2003 reached $169 million. Many of these companies are headquartered in modern industrial parks, one of the newest and most technologically advanced being [[El Marques Industrial Park]]. This facility was inaugurated in 2003, with an initial investment of $13 million USD. The park occupies a space of {{convert|274|acre|km2}} with international tenants from Italy, Germany, Spain, the US, Taiwan as well as Mexico representing real estate, automotive, carton packing, food processing and some high tech enterprises. One of these tenants is [[Siemens]] whose {{convert|4000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} plant is dedicated to manufacturing equipment for high voltage systems.{{cite press release |title=Mexico has obtain (sic) over 80 billion dollars in foreign direct investment during this administration |publisher= SecretarÃ­a de EconomÃ­a |date= February 2, 2011 |url=http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:zjumpH4S2AcJ:www.economia.gob.mx/swb/work/models/economia/Resource/1350/1/images/siemens.pdf+quer%C3%A9taro+economy&hl=es&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjuEXycFOwoipK7DzEtKNLKMCS1b3KCNHkiKCJIP2hLhVf5drm9GhNH-xhwxOkTDj_lBglJ9hQn0m0C9sRHc2UGIz_mpp90pRWdn_P31N1-0doOOfd1v4ytcQHSCiqNDqXOdLI8&sig=AHIEtbSgUY3eZGBULACxnAYUq8N6f3A8Nw |accessdate=March 12, 2011 }} The city of QuerÃ©taro has become the most advanced center of the aeronautics industry in Mexico, anchored by plant belonging to Canadian conglomerate [[Bombardier Inc.|Bombardier]], which opened in 2005. This plant manufactures [[fuselage]]s and electrical system, recently adding wing production for the [[Learjet 85]], a non metallic plane. This plant is the largest of the 189 aeronautics facilities in Mexico, employing about 2,000 people. There are eight other aeronautics enterprises located in the state.{{cite news |title= QuerÃ©taro, centro aeronÃ¡utico |author= Luis Alberto Medina |url= http://www.elsiglodetorreon.com.mx/noticia/406613.queretaro-centro-aeronautico.html |newspaper=El Siglo de Torreon |location=Torreon, Mexico |date=January 11, 2009 |accessdate=March 12, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=QuerÃ©taro, aeronautical center }} The state is known for dairy products and wine. Two of QuerÃ©taroâs cities, [[San Juan del RÃ­o]] and [[Ezequiel Montes, QuerÃ©taro|Ezequiel Montes]], have thriving [[viniculture]]s. Some of the best comes from the Rancho Santa Marina just to the south of the capital in the municipality of [[El MarquÃ©s]]. Rancho Hondonada is another reputable producer as well as Quesos Vai, which specializes in [[Cheeses of Mexico|Mexican cheeses]] such as Oaxaca and panela. The 45-hectare vineyard grows four varieties of grapes: Saint Emilion, Macabeu, Sauvignon Blanc and Pinot Noir. A cave 25 meters (82 ft) below ground maintains a constant and ideal climate for wine cellaring. Other producers include La Redonda and Rancho Los Azteca. === Traditional handcrafts === [[File:MarbleDisplayVizarron.JPG|thumb|Marble objects at a shop in VizarrÃ³n]] Handcrafts produced in the state include baskets, textiles, metal objects, pottery and items made from wood, leather and paper. Mojiganga figures are made with a reed frame to which the cardboard is applied. Bernal is noted for its masks made of paper and plaster which are often molded. In the city of QuerÃ©taro they make masks and mojiganga items, as well as large paper sculptures such as the Judas figures, which are burned.JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 41-42. === Commerce, services and tourism === [[File:Cavas Freixenet, QuerÃ©taro.JPG|thumb|Wine cellar at Cavas Freixnet, Ezequiel Montes]] Commerce, services and tourism accounts for 57% of the stateâs GDP, led by commerce at 19% and services at 18% both related and not to tourism. This is an increase from 45% in 1970. Since the 1990s, the state has promoted its tourism industry, with attendance at international forums, and building of hotels and other infrastructure. The Centro de Congresos (Convention Center) of QuerÃ©taro was inaugurated in 2011 in order to attract more business travel to the state. The facility contains ten halls, with a capacity of 9,000 people.{{cite news |title= Inaugura gobernador Centro de Convenciones de QuerÃ©taro |url= http://rotativo.com.mx/queretaro/inaugura-gobernador-centro-de-convenciones-de-queretaro/51002/html/|newspaper= Diario Rotativo |location=QuerÃ©taro, Mexico |date=February 5, 2011 |accessdate=March 12, 2011 |language=Spanish |trans_title=Governor inaugurats the Convention Center of QuerÃ©taro }} There are two areas declared as historic monuments by the Mexican federal government, the historic center of QuerÃ©taro and the historic center of San Juan del RÃ­o. The historic center of QuerÃ©taro has been declared a [[World Heritage Site]] by [[UNESCO]]. Most historic and cultural attractions are located in the capital. Museums include the Museo de Arte de QuerÃ©taro, the Museo Regional de QuerÃ©taro, the Museo de la Ciudad, the Museo del Sitio de QuerÃ©taro and Museo de la MatemÃ¡tica. Outside of the capital, there are the Museo HistÃ³rico de la Sierra Gorda, Museo ArqueolÃ³gico y Minero de la Sierra and the Museo de la Muerte in San Juan del RÃ­o. Another major attraction is its 74-arched [[aqueduct of QuerÃ©taro|aqueduct]] built in the early 1700s. The aqueduct rises 23 meters (75 ft) above street level and conveyed drinking water to the city from regional springs until 1970. The founding of the city of QuerÃ©taro is celebrated in July with various cultural and gastronomic events. Conchero dancers go in procession to the La Cruz Church to commemorate the appearance of Saint James. QuerÃ©taro has a number of areas which lend themselves to ecotourism. In the deep canyons there are grottos, valleys, ravines and arroyos. In the higher areas there are forests of pines and holm oak, and tropical forests in the lower elevations. The area was declared a biological reserve and contains about 1,700 species of plants, some endemic only to the area. There are also 360 species of birds, 130 of mammals, and just over 100 of amphibians and reptiles. A number of these are in danger of extinction such as [[Ara (genus)|macaws]], the black bear, the porcupine and the [[spider monkey]] .{{cite journal |last= Reyna |first= Juan Carlos |year=2010 |month=October |title= Reserva de la Biosfera Sierra Gorda |trans_title=Sierra Gorda Biosphere Reserve |journal= Donde Ir |page=54 |location=Mexico City |publisher=RR Donnellery de Mexico S de RI de CV |language=Spanish }} The state promotes its wine and cheeses with a Ruta del Vino or Wine Route. [[File:La PeÃ±a de Bernal.JPG|thumb|left|PeÃ±a de Bernal]] QuerÃ©taro has one [[Pueblo MÃ¡gico]], [[San SebastiÃ¡n Bernal]]. It is the second most important of its kind in the Americas. == Transportation and communications == [[File:Carretera5702.jpg|thumb|Highway 57 in QuerÃ©taro]] The state has a total of 3,349.5 km of highways, almost all of which is paved. 571 km of this is federal highway, 880.90 is state highway and 1,885.70 are rural roads. This station is a transfer point for many who travel north or south in the country. Other major terminals exist in [[ColÃ³n, QuerÃ©taro|ColÃ³n]], [[Tequisquiapan]], Jalpan de Serra, San Juan del RÃ­o, Cadereyta and [[Amealco de Bonfil]]. The state has 338.9 km of rail line, much the same as it had when they were initially built in the early 20th century. They mostly carry freight and connect the cities of San Juan del RÃ­o, Tequisquiapan, [[Pedro Escobedo, QuerÃ©taro|Pedro Escobedo]], QuerÃ©taro, ColÃ³n and El MarquÃ©s. The [[QuerÃ©taro International Airport]] began operations in 2004, replacing the older Ing. Fernando Espinosa Gutierrez Airport. Located in the capital, the facility handles both cargo and passengers.{{cite web |url= http://www.aiq.com.mx/AIQ_INFO/historia.html |title= Historia |publisher=Aeropuerto Internacional de QuerÃ©taro |location=QuerÃ©taro |language=Spanish |accessdate=March 12, 2011 |trans_title=History }} The state has twenty radio stations, seventeen of which are commercial enterprises. Stations include XHUAQ, XHORT, XHOZ, XHOE, XHQTO, XHMQ, XHJHS, XHZQ, XHRQ, XEUAQ, XEQG, XEKH, XEXE, XWGV, XEQUE, XEJX, XEHY and XENA. Major newspapers and magazines include Noticias, Diario de QuerÃ©taro, Sol de San Juan, Financiero Regional, Nuevo Amanecer, Futuro de QuerÃ©taro, Para Comentar, Nuevo Milenio, Rotativo, AÃ±o 2000, Mundo de QuerÃ©taro, Agora, CabaÃ±uelas, El Imparcial, El Informador, Mass, Magazine, Reporte (Q), Rincones Queretanos, Radar and El Informador de Santa Rosa JÃ¡uregui. == Government == The state government is divided into the Legislative, Judicial and Executive branches under Article 23 of the state constitution. The executive branch is headed by the governor, under whom are a number of agencies, including the state secretary and the state attorney general. The Legislature is unicameral made up of representatives popularly elected in districts of th state. This legislature has a number of committees tasked with certain types of legislation. The Judiciary consists of a state supreme court and a system of various lower courts.{{cite web |url= http://www.inafed.gob.mx/work/templates/enciclo/queretaro/ |title= Gobierno |year=2005 |work= Enciclopedia de los Municipios de MÃ©xico QuerÃ©taro |publisher= Instituto Nacional para el Federalismo y el Desarrollo Municipal |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans_title=Government |accessdate=March 12, 2011 }} == Archeology == [[File:Las Ranas.jpg|thumb|Ruins at Las Ranas]] Humans have been living in the area for between 4000 and 6000 years, with the oldest settlements in the southern part. In the pre Hispanic period the area was important for its commercial routes which linked the Gulf Coast, the Huasteca Region and the central highlands of Mexico principally, but there is evidence of commercial traffic from much further away. This made the area one of cultural exchanges with various ethnicities. When the Spanish arrived, the area was inhabited by the [[Chichimeca|Chichimeca Jonaz]], the [[Huasteca people|Huastecas]], the [[Ximpece]]s and the [[Pame]]s.(arqueomex) Four archeological sites are open to the public: Las Ranas, Toluquilla, El Quirambal and El Cerrito. [[Las Ranas]] and [[Toluquilla]] are two sites located near each other in the southwest of the [[Sierra Gorda]], about ninety km northwest of [[Tequisquiapan]], in [[San JoaquÃ­n, QuerÃ©taro|San JoaquÃ­n]]. Both controlled the important commercial routes of the area which linked the [[Gulf of Mexico|Gulf Coast]] and the [[Mexican Plateau|central highlands of Mexico]], principally, but there is evidence of trade through here from even farther away. One economic activity important to both was the mining of [[cinnabar]] (mercury sulfate) which was highly prized as a red pigment in the pre Hispanic period.{{cite web |url= http://www.arqueomex.com/S8N4GVesp77.html |title= La Sierra Gorda de QuerÃ©taro |author=JosuÃ© Cornejo |publisher= ArqueologÃ­a Mexicana magazine |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans_title=The Sierra Gorda of QuerÃ©taro |accessdate=March 12, 2011}}{{cite web |url= http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/ranas-queretaro.html|title= Ranas (QuerÃ©taro) |first= Arturo |last= ChÃ¡irez |month=May |year=2001 |publisher=Mexico Desconocido magazine |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |accessdate=March 12, 2011 }}{{cite web |url= http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/toluquilla-queretaro.html |title= Toluquilla (QuerÃ©taro) |first= Arturo |last= ChÃ¡irez |month=May |year=2001 |publisher=Mexico Desconocido magazine |location=Mexico City |language=Spanish |accessdate=March 12, 2011 }} Las Ranas was established first, reaching its height between 200 and 600 CE, but remained an inhabited city until 100 CE. The main political buildings were constructed on two natural elevations which form a corner. These elevations were terraced in order to place the buildings of stone and mud, then covered in stone plates or tiles to form the facades. Other significant buildings include various temples and five [[Mesoamerican ball court]]s. Toluquilla is a smaller site, occupied from 300 CE to 1300CE. This site was a ceremonial, political and administrative center, located on the upper part of an elongated hill, surrounded by ravines. The structures consist of a series of pyramid bases of stone and mud covered in stone plates or tiles. It also contains four Mesoamerican ball courts, one of which is much larger than other similar ones in the area from the same time. There is also a building which shows evidence of stucco work. Later in its history, the area was invaded by the [[Chichimeca Jonaz]], but when the Spanish arrived both sites were abandoned. [[El Quirambal]] is located in the Sierra Gorda between [[Pinal de Amoles]] and [[Jalpan de Serra]], in the small community of San Juan. The ruins lie top of a hill and their construction is similar to other sites in the [[La Huasteca|Huasteca]] region from the end of the [[Mesoamerican chronology|Classic into the Post Classic periods (800-1200CE)]]. One important structure is a Mesoamerican ball court which measures forty by twenty meters. On one side of this court, there is a temple with a pyramid base fourteen meters long and seven meters high. All along this flat topped hill, there are structures such as pyramid bases and dwellings and semi circular structures whose purpose has not been determined. The area was inhabited as early as 200 CE and stayed there until it was abandoned in 1200CE. During that time, much of the economy was based on primitive mining.JimÃ©nez GonzÃ¡lez, p 60. [[File:Piramide de El pueblito.jpg|thumb|Pyramid at El Cerrito]] [[El Cerrito (site)|El Cerrito]] is located in the municipality of [[Corregidora, Municipality|Corregidora]], only ten minutes from the historic center of the municipal seat. Twenty three million pesos has been budgeted for its restoration. Only part of the site is open to visitors, which focuses on the El Cerrito pyramid, which is illuminated on certain occasions. This pyramidâs dimensions are similar to that of the [[Pyramid of the Moon]] in [[Teotihuacan]]. This is one of the main tourist attractions of the area. The name comes from the fact that the site was part of the El Cerrito Hacienda, named after the site, which then was only a âhillâ covered in vegetation. The site was an important Toltec influenced ceremonial center, later occupied by the Chichimecas. Later, the area was converted into the sanctuary of the âVirgen de El Pueblitoâ Virgin Mary image for about a century. Besides the pyramid, another significant structure is called âEl FortÃ­n (The Small Fort), which was built over a pre Hispanic pyramid base in 1876, with [[Gothic Revival Architecture|Neo Gothic doors and windows]].{{cite web |url= http://www.terra.com.mx/Turismo/articulo/714926/El+Cerrito+nuevo+atractivo+en+Queretaro.htm |title= El Cerrito, nuevo atractivo en QuerÃ©taro |date=August 11, 2008 |publisher=Terra News |location=Mexico |language=Spanish |trans_title=El Cerrito, new attraction in QuerÃ©taro |accessdate=March 12, 2011}} The [[La Campana (site)|La Campana]] archeological site has been sacked and severely damaged. The site is the most important in the northwest of the state, corresponding to the Huasteca culture dating from the year 600 CE. The site was discovered in the mid 20th century, but has not been excavated due to the lack of funds. It contains 160 structures including platforms, plazas, patios, and more.{{cite news |title= ArqueÃ³logos denuncian saqueo en QuerÃ©taro |agency=Agencia el Universal |newspaper=El Universal |location=Mexico City |date=January 9, 2011 |page= |language=Spanish |trans_title=Archeologists denounce sacking in QuerÃ©taro}} Other discoveries in the state have included that of a 2,300 year old mummy of a female child, with accompanying fabric, hair, feathers and plant remains. The find was at a cave in a dry, cold, high-altitude site in the Sierra Gorda region. It is one of the oldest mummies found in Mexico, and was due to natural causes rather than by any preservation technique. The girl is estimated to have died around 320 BCE.{{cite news |title= Archeologists discover 2.300-year-old mummy in Mexico; [Source: El Universal] |newspaper=NoticiasFinancieras. |location=Miami
